title: The terrors of sleep paralysis - Ami Angelowicz

multiple-choice.question: What is sleep paralysis?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition where a person is awake and aware of their surroundings, but is unable to move or speak.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition where a person is asleep and dreaming, but is able to move and interact with their environment.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where a person is awake and aware of their surroundings, but is experiencing hallucinations and a sense of fear or panic.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where a person is asleep and dreaming, but is experiencing a sense of euphoria or relaxation.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the estimated percentage of the population that has experienced sleep paralysis at least once in their life?
What is the name of the medical professional who was the first to study sleep paralysis in 1867?
According to the transcript, what is the cause of sleep paralysis?

options.label: A
options.text: An abnormal overlap of the REM and waking stages of sleep.

multiple-choice.question: What is REM atonia, and what is its function during sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: REM atonia is a condition where a person is unable to move or speak during REM sleep, and its function is to keep the person from acting out their dreams.

options.label: B
options.text: REM atonia is a condition where a person is able to move and interact with their environment during REM sleep, and its function is to allow the person to experience a sense of euphoria or relaxation.

options.label: C
options.text: REM atonia is a condition where a person is awake and aware of their surroundings, and its function is to allow the person to experience a sense of fear or panic.

options.label: D
options.text: REM atonia is not a real condition, and its function is unknown.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the combination of the body's fear response and the brain being wide awake during a sleep paralysis episode?

options.label: A
options.text: The person experiences a sense of euphoria or relaxation.

options.label: B
options.text: The person is unable to move or speak.

options.label: C
options.text: The person experiences a struggle for air and a perceived sensation of pressure on the chest or suffocation.

options.label: D
options.text: The person experiences a sense of fear or panic.

In what region is the entity known as Phi Am said to reside?

options.label: A
options.text: Many people experience sleep paralysis regularly.

options.label: B
options.text: A few people experience sleep paralysis regularly.

options.label: C
options.text: Most people experience sleep paralysis regularly.

options.label: D
options.text: No one experiences sleep paralysis regularly.

title: A rare, spectacular total eclipse of the sun - Andy Cohen

multiple-choice.question: What is a total solar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: A partial eclipse where the Moon doesn't quite line up with the Sun.

options.label: B
options.text: A rare occasion where the Moon is too far from Earth in its orbit to completely cover the Sun.

options.label: C
options.text: A rare event where the shadow of the Moon will make a narrow path across Earth and those in the shadows will see a total solar eclipse.

options.label: D
options.text: A normal lunar eclipse where the Earth passes between the Sun and the Moon.

options.label: A
options.text: The date of the first solar eclipse.

options.label: B
options.text: The date of the first lunar eclipse.

options.label: C
options.text: The date of a battle between the armies of Lydia and Media.

options.label: D
options.text: The date of the first total solar eclipse.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it possible for the Moon to perfectly cover the disc of the Sun during a total solar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Moon is 400 times bigger than the Sun.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Sun is 400 times bigger than the Moon.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Moon is 390 times closer to Earth than the Sun.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Sun and Moon are the same size.

multiple-choice.question: What happens during an annular or partial eclipse?

options.label: C
options.text: The Sun's corona appears as a fiery ring around the dark disc of the moon.

options.label: D
options.text: The Moon completely covers the Sun.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the eclipse of 2017 remarkable?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the first total solar eclipse in human history.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is the first total solar eclipse in the United States.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Moon is slowly moving away from Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Sun and Moon are the same size.

multiple-choice.question: What will happen to the Moon's distance from Earth in the future?

options.label: D
options.text: It will become too far from Earth to completely cover the Sun.

multiple-choice.question: What should be used to observe the Sun during a total eclipse?

options.label: B
options.text: Specially tinted filters, specifically designed to observe the Sun.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it dangerous to look directly at the Sun during a total eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Sun is too bright.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Sun's corona can cause eye damage.

options.label: C
options.text: C: Because the Sun is too small.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Moon is too close to the Sun.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Sun's outer atmosphere called?

options.label: B
options.text: It will appear as a dark ring around the Sun.

options.label: C

title: Animation basics: The optical illusion of motion - TED-Ed

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon that occurs when we see a series of still images in quick succession, creating the illusion of motion?

What is the general threshold of our awareness of seeing separate images?
What is the continuous interaction of various computations in the visual cortex that stitch different aspects of what the eye sees together and culminate in the perception?
